entries.title: Africa: 'It would be too easy to see the hand of Moscow as the sole reason behind France's spectacular ouster'
entries.description: In his column for 'Le Monde', editorialist Philippe Bernard says that as French soldiers are expelled from Mali and Burkina Faso, France must accept its own complicity in the failures of independent African nations and see these events as a new phase of decolonization.

entries.title: 'League of LOL': Dismissal of investigation confirms the 2019 harassment scandal is fading
entries.description: The Paris prosecutor's office has decided that the accusations of cyber harassment against this group of journalists and communicators were insufficiently defined.

entries.title: DRC: UN peacekeeper killed in attack on helicopter
entries.description: MONUSCO chief Bintou Keita said she 'strongly condemns this cowardly attack on an aircraft bearing the UN emblem', adding that 'attacks against peacekeepers can constitute a war crime'.

entries.title: Head of UN's human rights mission in Mali expelled from country
entries.description: The decision comes after a Malian rights activist last month denounced the security situation in the country in a speech to a UN gathering, and accused the regime's new Russian military partners of serious rights violations.

entries.title: Multiple skiers killed in Austrian avalanches
entries.description: Austrian police said that over the weekend, eight people were killed in avalanches in the west of the country.

entries.title: Six Nations Rugby Championship France scores narrow win against Italy
entries.description: The French national team, which is ranked No. 2 in the world, won 29-24.

entries.title: Three French luxury hotels are in financial turmoil
entries.description: Hotels owned by businessman Michel Ohayon in Versailles, the Charles de Gaulle airport and Bordeaux have been placed in receivership for failure to repay loans.

entries.title: After Koran burnings in Stockholm and Copenhagen, Sweden wants to avoid a crisis
entries.description: Engaged in negotiations to join NATO, the Scandinavian country must deal with the anger being provoked in many countries by extremist Rasmus Paludan.

entries.title: In a messy world, Marie Kondo gives up on being tidy
entries.description: The organizational guru admitted that with the arrival of her third child, she has stopped applying her strict rules, and many of her followers have also abandoned them.

entries.title: Cyprus: Presidential election dominated by cost of living and tensions with Turkey
entries.description: Three candidates are vying to succeed Nicos Anastasiades, who has been in power for 10 years. Central issues include island reunification and the exploitation of gas fields.

entries.title: Series break: Episode 3 of 'The Last of Us' features love in the time of zombies
entries.description: 'Long Long Time,' the series' third episode, departs from the narrative of the video game from which it is adapted to showcase a heartbreaking romance between two men.

entries.title: Six Nations Rugby Championship: The start of a crucial year for Les Bleus
entries.description: After winning the Grand Slam last year, the French rugby team begins the 2023 Six Nations tournament on Sunday with an eye to the World Cup in September-October.

entries.title: US: Democrats approve 2024 presidential primary order change
entries.description: The first primary will be held next year in South Carolina, instead of Iowa, a shakeup that should help President Joe Biden if he decides to run again.

entries.title: Diplomatic crisis escalates after US destroys Chinese spying balloon
entries.description: A US fighter jet ended the flight of the surveillance aircraft over US airspace on February 5. The Chinese Foreign Ministry condemned the attack on 'a civilian unmanned airship.'

entries.title: Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan martial ruler in 9/11 wars, dies
entries.description: General Musharraf faced many controversies as president, from supporting the US war in Afghanistan to giving himself sweeping powers to rule the South Asian country.

entries.title: Between satisfaction and disillusionment, the European single market celebrates its 30th anniversary
entries.description: In January 1993, the free movement of goods, services, people, and capital was introduced between member states of the European Union in order to strengthen their economic integration. While the commercial benefits are undeniable, it has also had mixed effects and intensified the brain drain in the east of Europe.

entries.title: The French town still disturbed by the memory of Ayatollah Khomeini
entries.description: In 1979, Khomeini spent his last months in exile in Neauphle-le-Château, in the Paris region. On January 25, the sign marking the leader's connection to the town was vandalized.

entries.title: Short of doctors, Senegal faces a brain drain to France
entries.description: France recently presented a law that could make it easier for foreign doctors to come to the country.

entries.title: Video game coaching, a booming business
entries.description: With the growing popularity of esports, a wide range of personalized courses given by experienced gamers has been growing online in recent years.

entries.title: Lula takes action to end gold mining in the indigenous Yanomami territory
entries.description: The Lula government wants to cut off supplies to the gold miners who have invaded and polluted the territory in the Amazon with mercury, causing famine among this indigenous people.

entries.title: In Copenhagen, a fashion week in sustainable style
entries.description: Denmark's capital has placed environmental responsibility at the heart of its fashion week, highlighting young and daring designers with affordable wardrobes.

entries.title: Two former Guantanmo prisoners on a mission to prevent the radicalization of young Muslims
entries.description: Celebrating the release of a comic book that traces their journey from French suburbs to an Al-Qaeda camp and then Guantanamo Bay, Mourad Benchellali and Nizar Sassi look to raise awareness about the pitfalls of radicalization threatening suburban youth.

entries.title: Ukraine fends off latest Russian assault on Bakhmut
entries.description: Officials meanwhile recovered the bodies of two British volunteers, killed trying to help evacuate people from the eastern warzone.

entries.title: Reasons for Sweden's NATO membership deadlock
entries.description: To overcome the opposition of Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Stockholm has tried everything, but in vain.

entries.title: Pension reform: Elisabeth Borne announces that those who started working between the ages of 20 and 21 will be able to retire at 63
entries.description: The Prime Minister's announcement comes at the request of the elected representatives of the right, who want to avoid forcing those who started working the earliest to have to work the longest.
